metric.description: The product type representing the target platform.
The vendor id of this system, indicating the company that has supplied the product.
The CPU architecture type of this appliance

This indicates the overall status of the appliance. The algorithm to determine the value uses both hardware status (e.g. the number of failed fans) and volume status (e.g. number of volumes that are full). The algorithm is subject to change in future rele
Clustered Failover configuration settings. The value notConfigured(1) indicates that the cluster is not licensed. The thisNodeDead(5) setting indicates that this node has been taken over.
Clustered Failover state.
The reason this node cannot takeover its partner
This is the status last returned by the Clustered Failover partner.
The current status of the interconnect. The partialFailure(3) status indicates that one of the links in the interconnect hardware is down.
An indication of whether the hardware is currently operating outside of its recommended temperature range. The hardware will shutdown if the temperature exceeds critical thresholds.

An indication of the current status of the NVRAM battery or batteries. Batteries which are fully or partially discharged may not fully protect the system during a crash. The end-of-life status values are based on the manufacturer's recommended life.
An indication of the current status of autosupport on the appliance. describes the success or failure of most recent attempts to send autosupports.
Whether the nfs protocol is licensed on the filer.
Indicates whether the root volume's quotas are ON, OFF or initializing. This object is deprecated - use qvStateTable.qvStateStat instead.

An indication of overall file system health. 'ok' indicates that all file systems have adequate space. 'nearlyFull' means that one or more is nearly full (more than 95% full). 'full' means that one or more are more than 98% full.
Whether the CIFS protocol is active on the filer.
Whether new CIFS connections to the filer are currently allowed.

Has the filer joined an NT domain? If this value is true, cifsDomainName will contain the name of the domain. Otherwise, the filer may have joined a WorkGroup, and cifsWGName will contain the name of the WorkGroup.
True if WINS name resolution is enabled on the filer.

Which type of authentication semantics (Unix or PC) are in use for PC access to Unix files on the filer. If Unix semantics are in use, no ACL on a Unix file is ever checked. If PC semantics are in use, the share level ACL on the share containing the file
Whether oplocks are enabled on the filer.
Whether level 2 oplocks are enabled on the filer.
If this option is set to preserve-case (the default), all filename references will be case preserving. Otherwise, they are forced to lowercase.
If this option is enabled, CIFS accesses will follow symbolic links using Unix semantics.
If this option is enabled, CIFS accesses will through symbolic links will check for cycles in the link graph.
Whether the CIFS protocol is licensed on the filer.
True when cifs.per_client_stats are being collected.

This indicates whether the cifs clients are using clear text passwords when authenticating with the filer. If cifsDomainJoined is false and this variable is also false, then the filer is using NT Security from a local user list.
Whether Netcache is enabled on this system.
Whether Netcache is licensed on this system.
Whether the Domain Name System (DNS) is enabled on this system.
Whether HTTP is enabled on this system.
Whether NNTP is enabled on this system.
Whether NNTP is licensed on this system.
Whether Microsoft Media Services (MMS) is enabled on this system.
Whether Microsoft Windows Media Service (MMS) is licensed on this system.
Whether Microsoft Windows Media Service Pro (MMS) is licensed on this system.
Whether the Real Time Streaming Protocol (RTSP) is enabled on this system.
Whether QuickTime is licensed on this system.
Whether Real Media streaming is licensed on this system.
Whether Microsoft Windows Media Service Ultra (MMS) is licensed on this system.
Whether Real Media Pro streaming is licensed on this system.
Whether Real Media Ultra streaming is licensed on this system.
Whether ICAP v0.95 is enabled on this system.
Whether ICAP is licensed on this system.
Whether ICAP v1.0 is enabled on this system.
Whether the Global Request Manager (GRM) Server is enabled on this system.
Whether the Global Request Manager (GRM) Server is licensed on this system.
Whether the Global Request Manager (GRM) Agent enabled on this system.
Whether the Global Request Manager (GRM) Agent is licensed on this system.
Whether Content Director is enabled on this system.
Whether HTTPS is enabled on this system.
Whether HTTPS is licensed on this system.
Whether CMS is enabled on this system.
Has Full Service Resolver been enabled
Has Full Service Resolver initalised
Whether a possible ntlm problem is detected in the appliance's domain environment.
Indicates whether snapmirror has been turned on or not.
Whether the snapmirror is licensed on the filer.
Indicates whether snapvault has been turned on or not.
Whether the snapvault_client(primary) is licensed on the filer.
Whether the snapvault_server(secondary) is licensed on the filer.
Whether the snapvault disaster recovery primary is licensed on the filer.
Indicates whether ndmpd has been turned on or not.
Indicates whether ftpd has been turned on or not.
Server uses checksums
Allow the server to acception connections with authentication type NONE.
Current status of the DAFS server. If true, the DAFS server is running.
Whether vfiler is licensed on the filer.
Whether FCP access protocols are licensed on the filer.
Whether iSCSI access protocols are licensed on the filer.
Failover setting for the FCP target cluster.
Whether NFS caching is enabled on this system.
Whether NFS caching is licensed on this system.
Indicates whether Advanced SIS is licensed on the filer.
Indicates whether compression is licensed on the filer.
Variable for user defined SNMP traps to monitor whether there has been a status change of any of the acceleration servers that netcache is probing.
Whether the local configuration file on NetCache was changed without using DFM configuration management.
Variable for user defined SNMP traps to monitor whether there has been a status change of any of the GRM agents reporting to this GRM server.
Indicates the current takeover mode of this appliance.

Indicates the current status of the takeover partner of this appliance. up(1) indicates that the takeover partner is reachable. unknown(2) indicates that an unknown error occured. failed(3) indicates that the partner has failed, takeoverAddrs indicates th
The IP address of the referenced client.
The total number of RPC calls received from the referenced client, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The total number of calls received from the referenced client that were rejected by the RPC layer, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of times an RPC call was not available when it was thought to be received from referenced client, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of RPC calls received from the referenced client with a length shorter than a minimum-sized RPC call, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of RPC calls received from the referenced client whose header could not be XDR decoded, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The total number of NFS calls received from the referenced client, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The total number of NFS calls received from the referenced client that were rejected, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_NULL (Do Nothing) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_GETATTR (Get File Attributes) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_SETATTR (Set File Attributes) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_ROOT (Get Filesystem Root) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_LOOKUP (Look Up File Name) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_READLINK (Read From Symbolic Link) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_READ (Read From File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_WRITECACHE (Write to Cache) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_WRITE (Write to File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_CREATE (Create File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_REMOVE (Remove File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_RENAME (Rename File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_LINK (Create Link to File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_SYMLINK (Create Symbolic Link) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_MKDIR (Create Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_RMDIR (Remove Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_READDIR (Read From Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_STATFS (Get Filesystem Attributes) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_NULL (Do Nothing) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_GETATTR (Get File Attributes) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_SETATTR (Set File Attributes) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_LOOKUP (Lookup Filename) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_ACCESS (Check Access Permission) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_READLINK (Read from Symbolic Link) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_READ (Read From File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_WRITE (Write to File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_CREATE (Create a File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_MKDIR (Create a Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_SYMLINK (Create a Symbolic Link) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_MKNOD (Create a Special Device) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_REMOVE (Remove a File) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_RMDIR (Remove a Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_RENAME (Rename a File or Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_LINK (Create Link to an Object) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_READDIR (Read From Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_READDIRPLUS (Extended Read from Directory) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_FSSTAT (Get Dynamic File System Information) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_FSINFO (Get Static File System Information) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_PATHCONF (Retrieve POSIX Information) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.

The number of NFS Version 3 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC3_COMMIT (Commit Cached Data on a Server to Stable Storage) procedure, since the last time the statistics were cleared.
The number of the total NFS calls for the referenced client as a percentage of the total NFS calls received from all clients, since the last time the statistics were cleared.

The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_NULL (Do Nothing) procedure, as a percentage of the total calls received from this client, since the last time the statistics were cleared.

The number of NFS Version 2 calls received from the referenced client for the NFSPROC_GETATTR (Get File Attributes) procedure, as a percentage of the total calls received from this client, since the last time the statistics were cleared.

The number of NFS Version 2 read calls with request sizes between 0-511 bytes received from this client.
The number of NFS Version 2 read calls with request sizes between 512-1023 bytes received from this client.
The number of NFS Version 2 read calls with request sizes between 1K-2047 bytes received from this client.
The number of NFS Version 2 read calls with request sizes between 2K-4095 bytes received from this client.
The number of NFS Version 2 read calls with request sizes between 4K-8191 bytes received from this client.
The number of NFS Version 2 read calls with request sizes between 8K-16383 bytes received from this client.

The number of NFS Version 2 read calls with request sizes between 64K-131071 bytes received from this client.
The number of NFS Version 2 write calls with request sizes between 0-511 bytes received from this client.

The number of NFS Version 3 write calls with request sizes between 32K-65535 bytes received from this client.
The number of NFS Version 3 write calls with request sizes between 64K-131071 bytes received from this client.
A number that identifies this entry in the file /etc/quotas.
Identifies the kind of quota for this qrEntry.
The UID (user's numerical ID) or the GID (numerical ID of the group that a user belongs to), as applicable, associated with this qrEntry.
The current number of KBytes used for this qrEntry.
The limit of KBytes that can be used for this qrEntry.
The current number of files used for this qrEntry.
The limit of files that can be used for this qrEntry.
A textual string that contains the path corresponding to this qrEntry.

A number that identifies this volume. The mapping of this number to actual volumes may change if volumes are added or deleted. Use qvStateName to unambiguously identify a volume. The mapping established by this object is the same as the mapping of qrVVolu
Indicates the name of this volume.
Indicates whether quotas are ON, OFF or initializing.
Indicates percentage of quota computation done while quotas are in initializing state.
A number that identifies this entry in the file /etc/quotas in the given volume.
Identifies the kind of quota for this qrVEntry.
The UID (user's numerical ID) or the GID (numerical ID of the group that a user belongs to), as applicable, associated with this qrVEntry. Check the qrVIdType field to see if this field is valid.
The current number of KBytes used for this qrVEntry.
The limit of KBytes that can be used for this qrVEntry.
The current number of files used for this qrVEntry.
The limit of files that can be used for this qrVEntry.
A textual string that contains the path corresponding to this qrVEntry.

A number that identifies the volume for which this quota is in effect on. The volume that this value represents can be determined by checking the value of qvStateName (above) with qvStateVolume set to the value found here.
A string that indicates which qtree this quota belongs to.
A value that indicates which ID field is valid.

The one or more IDs associated with this qrVEntry. If the qrVentry is associated with a Windows ID, the text form of the Windows ID (the SID) is here. If the qrVEntry is associated with more than one id, this contains a blank separated list of those IDs.
A number of KBytes that when used by this entry produces a warning message.
The limit of KBytes that can be used for this qrVEntry before a warning message and SNMP trap is produced.
The limit of files that can be used for this qrVEntry before a warning message and SNMP trap is produced.
A number that identifies this entry in the file /etc/quotas in the given volume.
Identifies the kind of quota for this qrV2Entry.
The UID (user's numerical ID) or the GID (numerical ID of the group that a user belongs to), as applicable, associated with this qrV2Entry. Check the qrV2IdType field to see if this field is valid.
The current number of KBytes used for this qrV2Entry.

This flag designates whether or not the size based quota limit for this qrV2Entry is unlimited. If false(1) then qrV2*KBytesLimit OID's are valid, if true(0) then qrV2*KBytesLimit OID's are unused and will return 0.
The limit of KBytes that can be used for this qrV2Entry.
The current number of files used for this qrV2Entry.
This flag designates whether or not the file based quota limit for this qrV2Entry is unlimited. If false(1) then qrV2FileLimit is valid, if true(0) qrV2FileLimit will return 0.
The limit of files that can be used for this qrV2Entry.
A textual string that contains the path corresponding to this qrV2Entry.

A number that identifies the volume for which this quota is in effect on. The volume that this value represents can be determined by checking the value of qvStateName (above) with qvStateVolume set to the value found here.
A string that indicates which qtree this quota belongs to.
A value that indicates which ID field is valid.

The one or more IDs associated with this qrV2Entry. If the qrV2entry is associated with a Windows ID, the text form of the Windows ID (the SID) is here. If the qrV2Entry is associated with more than one id, this contains a blank separated list of those ID

This flag designates whether or not the size based threshold limit for this qrV2Entry is unlimited. If false(1) then qrV2*KBytesThreshold OID's are valid, if true(0) then qrV2*KBytesThreshold OID's are unused and will return 0.
A number of KBytes that when used by this entry produces a warning message.

This flag designates whether or not the size based soft quota limit for this qrV2Entry is unlimited. If false(1) then qrV2*KBytesSoftLimit OID's are valid, if true(0) the qrV2*KBytesSoftLimit OID's are unused and will return 0.
The limit of KBytes that can be used for this qrV2Entry before a warning message and SNMP trap is produced.

This flag designates whether or not the file based soft quota limit for this qrV2Entry is unlimited. If false(1) then qrV2SoftFileLimit is valid, if true(0) qrV2SoftFileLimit is unused and will return 0.
The limit of files that can be used for this qrV2Entry before a warning message and SNMP trap is produced. This will return 0 if qrV2SoftFileQuotaUnlimited is true.
The current number of KBytes used for this qrV2Entry.
The limit of KBytes that can be used for this qrV2Entry.
A number of KBytes that when used by this entry produces a warning message.
The limit of KBytes that can be used for this qrV2Entry before a warning message and SNMP trap is produced.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced file system.
The name for the referenced file system.
The total capacity in KBytes for the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is in use on the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is free for use on the referenced file system.
The percentage of disk space currently in use on the referenced file system.
The total number of inodes in use on the referenced file system.
The total number of inodes that are available for use on the referenced file system.
The percentage of disk space currently in use based on inode counts, on the referenced file system.
The name of the file on which this file system is mounted.
The count of the maximum number of files allowable on the referenced file system.
The count of the number of files currently in use on the referenced file system.
The largest value to which the filesysMaxfilesAvail parameter above can be increased by reconfiguration on the referenced file system.
The total capacity in KBytes for the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is in use on the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is free for use on the referenced file system.
The status of the file system.
Overall mirror status of the file system.
Number of plexes in this file system.
Indicates the type of container.
The total amount of data in KBytes that is shared by more that one instance on the referenced file system.

The total disk space in KBytes that is saved by storing only one copy of the duplicated blocks on the referenced file system. The object returns the most significant 32 bits of the 64 bit unsigned integer.
The percentage of disk space saved by eliminating the duplicated blocks on the referenced file system.
The total capacity in KBytes for the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is in use on the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is free for use on the referenced file system.
The total amount of data in KBytes that is shared by more that one instance on the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is saved by storing only one copy of the duplicated blocks on the referenced file system. The object returns all of the 64 bit unsigned integer.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced file system.
The month in which the snapshot was created.
The day on which the snapshot was created.
The hour in which the snapshot was created.
The minute in which the snapshot was created.
The name of the referenced snapshot.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced file system.
The month in which the snapshot was created.
The day on which the snapshot was created.
The hour in which the snapshot was created.
The minute in which the snapshot was created.
The name of the referenced snapshot.
A number that identifies the volume / aggregate that contains this snapshot.
Number of snapshots for this volume / aggregate.
The name of the volume / aggregate. This does not have a /vol/ prefix.
Indicates the type of container for this snapshot.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced file system.
A number that identifies the volume that contains this snapshot.
A number that identifies the qtree that contains this snapshot.
The name of the referenced snapshot.
Time of the snapshot on the system. The time in seconds since January 1, 1970.
A string that indicates which qtree is in this snapshot
The content of the qtree tree
The source of this qtree for a replicated qtree. '-' for a original qtree.
Time of the source snapshot for a replicated qtree. Time of the current snapshot for an original qtree. The time in seconds since January 1, 1970. 0 if the qtree is in a transitioning stage
The name of the volume. This does not have a /vol/ prefix.
A number that identifies this volume. The volIndex is not related to any other table defined in this MIB, and may change as volumes are created and destroyed.
Name of the volume. This includes no /vol/ prefix.
Unique identifier for this volume.
Indication of which host owns this volume.
State of the volume, such as 'online' or 'offline'.
Status of the volume, such as 'normal' or 'reconstructing'. May include several values separated by comma and space.
Options associated with the volume, such as 'root' and 'nosnapdir=off'. May include several values separated by comma.
A unique id associated with the volume.
Name of the aggregate this flexible volume is a part of.
Type of this volume, older volumes are traditional while newer volumes contained in aggregates are flexible.
True indicates flexible volume is a clone.
Name of flexible volume this flexible volume is a clone of.
Name of original cloned snapshot.
Index into the qtree table.
A number that identifies the volume that contains this qtree.
The name of the volume that contains this qtree. This includes no /vol/prefix.
The Id number of the qtree.
The name of the qtree.
The security style of the qtree.
The status of the qtree.
An indication of whether the oplocks is enabled or not for this qtree.
A number that identifies this aggregate. The aggrIndex is not related to any other table defined in this MIB, and may change as aggregates are created and destroyed.
Name of the aggregate. This includes no /vol/ prefix.
Unique identifier for this aggregate.
Indication of which host owns this aggregate.
State of the aggregate, such as 'online' or 'offline'.
Status of the aggregate, such as 'normal' or 'reconstructing'. May include several values separated by comma and space.
Options associated with the aggregate.
A unique id associated with the aggregate.
List of all the flexible volumes within this aggregate.
Type of this container, containers containing flexible volumes are aggregate.
Type of raid protection of the aggregate, such as 'raid0', 'mirrored raid0', 'raid4', 'mirrored raid4', 'raid_dp', 'mirrored raid_dp'.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced disk drive.
The name identifying the referenced disk drive.
The status of the referenced disk drive.
The disk identifier for the referenced disk drive.
The identifier of the SCSI adapter for the referenced disk drive.
The identifier for the referenced disk drive on the referenced SCSI adapter.
The number of MBytes currently in use on the referenced disk drive.
The number of Blocks currently in use on the referenced disk drive.
The number of MBytes physically available on the referenced disk drive.
The number of Blocks physically available on the referenced disk drive.

In the case when reconstruction/adding a spare, verification or scrubbing is in progress, the percent of such reconstruction, verification or scrubbing that has been completed on the referenced disk drive.
A number that identifies this disk drive within the given volume and RAID group.
The name identifying the referenced disk drive.
The status of the referenced disk drive.
The disk identifier for the referenced disk drive.
The identifier of the SCSI adapter for the referenced disk drive.
The identifier for the referenced disk drive on the referenced SCSI adapter.
The number of MBytes currently in use on the referenced disk drive.
The number of Blocks currently in use on the referenced disk drive.
The number of MBytes physically available on the referenced disk drive.
The number of Blocks physically available on the referenced disk drive.

In the case when rapid raid recovery, disk copy, reconstruction/adding a spare, verification or scrubbing is in progress, the percent of such copy, reconstruction, verification or scrubbing that has been completed on the referenced disk drive.
A number that identifies the volume that this entry belongs to. The first volume is '1'.
A number that identifies the RAID group within the given volume that this entry belongs to. The first RAID group is '1', and number across all plexes.
The number of disks within this RAID group.
The number of RAID groups within this volume.

A number that indicates which port of the disk is being used by the primary path to the disk. For a dual-ported disk, values of portA and portB indicate which port is being used. If the disk only has a single port, the value is portSingle, and if the port
The name identifying the secondary path to the referenced disk drive.

A number that indicates which port of the disk is being used by the secondary path to the disk. For a dual-ported disk, values of portA and portB indicate which port is being used. If the disk only has a single port, the value is portSingle, and if the po
Number identifying the shelf where the disk is located.
Number identifying the disk bay within the shelf where the disk is located.
A number that identifies the plex within the given volume that this entry belongs to. The first plex is '1'.
A number that identifies the RAID group within the given plex that this entry belongs to. The first RAID group is '1'.
The number of plexes within this volume. This number is always 1 or 2.
A name that identifies the plex that this entry belongs to. A plex name can be anything, but is usually a string like 'plex0' or 'plex1'.
A number that specifies bytes per sector for this entry. Values are '512' or '520'.
Serial number of the referenced disk drive.
The vendor of the referenced disk drive.
Model string of the referenced disk drive.
Firmware revision number of the referenced disk drive.
RPM of the referenced disk drive.
Interface type of the referenced disk drive. e.g SCSI, or ATA.
A name that identifies the disk pool that this entry belongs to.
When raidVStatus value is prefailed, this string identifies the name of the disk which is the copy target of the referenced prefailed disk.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced disk drive in the list of spare disk drives.
The name identifying the referenced spare disk drive.
The status of the referenced spare disk drive.
The disk identifier for the referenced spare disk drive.
The identifier of the SCSI adapter for the referenced spare disk drive.
The identifier for the referenced spare disk drive on the referenced SCSI adapter.
The number of MBytes physically available on the referenced spare disk drive.
The number of Blocks physically available on the referenced spare disk drive.

A unique value for each entry in the acceleration monitor table.
The IP address of the acceleration server the NetCache is monitoring.
The corresponding port on the server that NetCache is monitoring.

The status of the service running on the server. active - in queue but no probes done yet. up - the server is reachable and responding to probes. down - the server is unreachable. inactive - monitoring is disabled.
A unique value for each entry in the http acceleration stats table
The total number of kilobytes received from the client for this acceleration rule
The total number of kilobytes sent to the client for this acceleration rule
The number of times this acceleration rule has been hit
A unique value for each entry in the http acceleration stats table
The total number of kilobytes received from the client for this acceleration rule
The total number of kilobytes sent to the client for this acceleration rule
The number of times this acceleration rule has been hit
A unique value for each entry in the streaming acceleration stats table
The total number of kilobytes received from the client for this acceleration rule
The total number of kilobytes sent to the client for this acceleration rule
The number of times this acceleration rule has been hit
Index into the snapmirror status table.
Source of the snapmirror. <filer>:<vol> or <filer>:/vol/<qtree_name>
Destination of the snapmirror. <filer>:<vol> or <filer>:/vol/<qtree_name>
Current transfer status of the snapmirror.
Current state of the snapmirror.
How far behind from the source the destination is.
Total number of successful transfer since the snapmirror is initialized. Persistent across reboot.
Total number of successful restarted transfer since the snapmirror is initialized. Persistent across reboot.
Total number of failed or aborted transfer since the snapmirror is initialized. Persistent across reboot.
Total number of deferment since the snapmirror is initialized. Persistent across reboot.
Total transfer size in MB for the snapmirror. Reset on reboot.
Total number of seconds spent in successful transfer for the snapmirror. Reset on reboot.
Current throttle value for the snapmirror.
Timestamp of the last snapshot successfully transferred from the source to the destination.
The name of the current base snapshot for the snapmirror.
The type of the previous successful transfer.
Last successful transfer size in MB for the snapmirror.
Duration of last successful transfer in seconds for the snapmirror.
Update schedule for the snapmirror in conf file format.
Description of the update schedule for the snapmirror.
Arguments for the snapmirror in conf file format.
The number of times changing from sync mode to async mode since the snapmirror is initialized. Persistent across reboot.
Index into the snapmirror multipath connection table.
The name of the snapmirror multipath connection.
The type of the snapmirror multipath connection.
The name of the source for the first path.
The name of the destination for the first path.
The name of the source for the second path.
The name of the destination for the second path.
Index into the snapvault status table.
Source of the snapvault relationship. <filer>:/vol/<qtree_name>
Destionation of the snapvault relationship. <filer>:/vol/<qtree_name>
Current transfer status of the snapvault relationship.
Current state of the snapvault relationship.
How far behind from the source the destination is.
Total number of successful transfer since the snapvault relationship was established. Persistent across reboot.
Total number of successful restarted transfer since the snapvault relationship was established. Persistent across reboot.
Total number of failed or aborted transfer since the snapvault relationship was established. Persistent across reboot.
Total number of deferment since the snapvault relationship was established. Persistent across reboot.
Total transfer size in MB for the snapvault. Reset on reboot.
Total number of seconds spent in successful transfer for the snapvault relationship. Reset on reboot.
Current throttle value for the snapvault relationship.
Time when the source snapshot was created. The time in seconds since January 1, 1970. The source snapshot here is the last snapshot successfully transferred from the source to the destination.
The name of the current base snapshot for the snapvault relationship.
The type of the previous successful transfer.
Last successful transfer size in MB for the snapvault relationship.
Duration of last successful transfer in seconds for the snapvault relationship.
Index into the snapvault remote host table.
The name of the remote snapvault host.
The type of the remote snapvault host.
Total number of successful snapvault transfers for all current established relationships between the local snapvault system and the given remote host.
Total number of failed snapvault transfers for all current established relationships between the local snapvault system and the given remote host.
Total number of deferred snapvault transfers for all current established relationships between the local snapvault system and the given remote host. 0 for snapvault client host.
Index into the snapvault schedule table.
The name of the volume on the snapvault for the snapvault schedule. This does not have a /vol/ prefix.
The name of the snapshot for the snapvault schedule.
Current status of the snapvault schedule.
The type of the snapvault schedule.
The update schedule of the snapvault.
A number that identifies this fabric entry.
This indicates the overall status of the SAN fabric(s).
A string describing the fabric status, including a description of the condition (if any) that caused the status to be anything other than ok(3).
This is the WWN of the fabric.
This indicates who owns the management of the fabric.
A number that identifies this switch entry.
This is the WWN of the switch.
This is the symbolic name of the switch.
The type of the switch.
The domain identifier of the switch.
The in-band management identifier of the switch.
The current status of the switch.
A string describing the switch status, including a description of the condition (if any) that caused the status to be anything other than ok(3).
The link speed of the switch. The value is an integer whose units are Gbits (for example, a value of 2 represents a link speed of 2 Gbit).
Number of Packets successfully processed since the last reboot/reset of the switch.
Number of Packets rejected since the last reboot/reset of the switch.
The index of the fabric on which this switch resides. The value ranges from 1 to the value of fabricInstances.
Number of Packets successfully processed since the last reboot/reset of the switch.
Number of Packets rejected since the last reboot/reset of the switch.
A number that identifies this port entry.
This is the WWN of the port.
The index of the switch on which this port resides. The value ranges from 1 to the number of of switches.
This is the WWN of the switch to which the port is attached.
The port number on the switch.
The type of the port.
The current state of the port.
The index of the fabric on which this port resides. The value ranges from 1 to the value of fabricInstances.
Index into the subtree dump table.
The full path to the dump subtree. In the format of /vol/<volname>/...
No. of dump attempted for the subtree.
No. of dump succeeded for the subtree.
No. of dump failed for the subtree.
The start time for the last attempt to dump the subtree, including the currently running one. The time in seconds since January 1, 1970.
The status for the last dump attempt on the subtree.
The level of the dump.
The number of files dumped.
The amount of data dumped, in Megabytes.
The start time of the dump. The time is in seconds since January 1, 1970.
The duration of the dump.

A unique value for each interface. Its value ranges between 1 and the value of DafsNicNumber. The value for each interface must remain constant at least from one re-initialization of the entity's network management system to the next re- initialization.
A textual string containing the logical name under which the nic has been attached.
A textual string containing the physical name of the nic that has been attached.
Current state of DAFS nic
Transport specific address structure giving the DAFS listen address for this NIC.
Total number of bytes, include DMA, received on this interface
Total number of bytes read directly from the peer memory through this interface
Total number of bytes, include DMA, sent on this interface
Total number of bytes written directly to the peer memory through this interface
A unique value for each session.
Session Identifier assigned by the server.
Byte order used on this session.
Session may use a back control channel.
Session may use a RDMA read channel.
Session uses checksums.
Maximum number of credientials that can be registered on this session.
Maximum size of a DAFS request.
Maximum size of a DAFS response.
Maximum number of concurrent requests.
Size of DAFS headers plus padding to the start of data. Used to better align inline data.
Client ID string supplied by the client. Intended to uniquely identify that client.
Supplied by the client to uniquely identify an instnce of a client.
Current number of credentials registered on this session
Current number of active requests on this session

A unique value for each export. Its value ranges between 1 and the number of exports. The value for each export must remain constant at least from one re-initialization of the entity's network management system to the next re- initialization.
A textual string containing information about the export. This is the logical export name.
A textual string containing information about the export. This is the local filesystem path to the export.
This export is available for access.
Global export mode. This represents the maximum access rights.
A textual string containing information about the export. This is the list of hosts that may access the export. If empty, all hosts may access the export.
The state of this via connection Legal States: Idle 1 Pending Connect 2 Connected 3 Error 4
A number which uniquely defines a connection.
IP address of the remote system of the connection.
Local IPadress of the connection.
Remote TCP portnumber of the connection.
Local TCP Portnumber of the connection.
An identifier used by the local process to identify the VI connection.
An identifier used by the remote process to identify the VI connection.
The local limit on the maximum packet size that can be transfered through the connection.
The remote limit on the maximum packet size that can be transfered through the connection.
The value is 1 if remote DMA write is enabled in the local system otherwise, it is 0.
The value is 1 if remote DMA read is enabled in the local system otherwise, it is 0.
The value is 1 if remote DMA write is enabled in the remote system otherwise, it is 0.
The value is 1 if remote DMA read is enabled in the remote system otherwise, it is 0.
Total number of messages sent through the connection.
Total number of rdma read messages sent through the connection.
Total number of rdma write messages sent through the connection.
Total number of messages received through the connection.
Total number of rdma read messages received through the connection.
Total number of rdma write messages received through the connection.
The index of the NIC in the NIC table.
The symbolic name of the NIC device.
The version of the VINIC described by this MIB.
The version of the VI provider.
The Network address of this NIC.
1 if synchronisation model is thread safe else 0.
The maximum number of bytes that the VI provider allows for a connection descriminator.
Maximum number of bytes that can be registered.
Maximum number of memory regions that can be registered.
Largest contiguous block of memory that can be registered.
The limit on the total number of VI instances this entity can support.
Maximum Descriptors per VI Work Queue that this VI provider can support.
Maximum number of segments per descriptor that this VI provider can support.
Maximum number of completion queues this VI provider can support.
Maximum number of Completion queue entries per completion queue that this VI provider can support.
The maximum transfer size supported by the VI Nic. The maximum transfer size is the amount of data that can be described by a single VI descriptor.

The native MTU size of the underlying network. For frame-based networks, this could reflect its native frame size. For cell-based networks, it could reflect the MTU of the appropriate abstraction layer that it supports.
The maximum number of protection tags that are supported by this VI provider.
Number of bytes registered by the VI user for this NIC.
Number of memory regions that is registered by VI user for this NIC.
The current number of VI instances for this NIC.
Current number of completion queues this VI provider has.
Current Number of protection tags this VI provider has.
Port number on which VI server is listening for VI connection request.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced vfiler.
A textual string that contains the name of the referenced vfiler.
The UUID of the referenced vfiler.
The total number of IP addresses for the referenced vfiler.
The total number of storage paths for the referenced vfiler.
A textual string that contains the name of the ipspace that the referenced vfiler belongs to.
Total number of protocols allowed for the referenced vfiler.
Total number of protocols disallowed for the referenced vfiler.
Status of the vfiler: Running or stopped.
A number that identifies the referenced vfiler.
A number that identifies which IP address in the referenced vfiler.
A IP address for the referenced vfiler.
A number that identifies the referenced vfiler.
A number that identifies which storage path in the referenced vfiler.
The storage path name for the referenced vfiler.
A number that identifies the referenced vfiler.
A number that identifies a protocol in the referenced vfiler.
A textual string that contains the protocol name for the referenced vfiler.
Whether the referenced vfiler protocol is allowed or disallowed.
A number that identifies the referenced LUN.
The name of the LUN. This is also the path to the LUN on the filer.
The comment, if any, for this LUN.
Size of the LUN in bytes.
This LUN has been mapped to at least one initiator group.
The 12 character SCSI serial number of the LUN.
A string that indicates which qtree this LUN belongs to.
The total number of Target side SCSI ops for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of bytes read from this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of bytes written to this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of errors seen on this LUN since the stats were last reset.
Whether the LUN is online.
Whether a snapshot of this LUN can be taken.
The sharing status for the LUN.
Whether the LUN has space reservation enabled.
Number of seconds since this LUN's stats were last reset.
The total number of Target side SCSI read ops for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of Target side SCSI write ops for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of Target side SCSI ops that are not read or write for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
Size of the LUN in bytes.
The total number of Target side SCSI ops for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of bytes read from this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of bytes written to this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of errors seen on this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of Target side SCSI read ops for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of Target side SCSI write ops for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
The total number of Target side SCSI ops that are not read or write for this LUN since the stats were last reset.
A number that identifies the LUN in the table.
A number that identifies an initiator group in the table.
The name of the LUN.
The name of the initiator group that this LUN is mapped to.
SCSI Logical Unit Number that this LUN is mapped to for this initiator group.
A number that identifies a specific initiator group.
The name of the initiator group
Type of this initiator group, either iSCSI or FCP
Operating system the clients in this initiator group run. This governs the finer details of SCSI protocol interaction with these initiators
Percentage of filer scsi command blocks reserved for this initiator group
True if this inititiator group is allowed to exceed it's throttle settings if more resources are needed and otherwise available. If initiatorGroupThrottleReserve is 0, this value is meaningless
The takeover mode for the initiator group. This is only applicable to FCP initiator groups on clustered filers
If true this initiator group supports Asymetric Logical Unit Access.
A number that identifies a specific initiator group.
A number the identifies the initiator in the group.
A textual name for this initiator.
A number that identifies the initiator connected to the target adapter.
The name of the target adapter in the filer.
A textual name for this initiator node.
The FibreChannel device's portname. This is FCP only.
Type of this init group, either iSCSI or FCP
The iSCSI isid (initiator session id) for this initiator. This is iSCSI only.
The iSCSI portal group ID for this initiator. This is iSCSI only.
A number that identifies a specific fcp target device.
The name of the fcp target device
The FC WWNN of the fcp target device
The FC WWPN of the fcp target device
speed in gigabits per second. 0 is unknown.
Status of the fcp target adapter
Whether this target adapter is in standby mode.
fibre channel topology for this adapter.
Responsibility/Type for this adapter.
A number that identifies a specific port set.
The name of the port set
Type of this port set, either iSCSI or FCP
A number that identifies a specific port set.
A number the identifies the port in the set.
A textual name for this port.

A number that identifies this enclosure among the possible monitored enclosures. This number normally uniquely identifies one shelf within one boot, but may it change between boots. The number may also change within a boot if shelves are removed and added
The state of the communication between the filer or storage engine and the enclosure monitoring device in the enclosure.
The adapter number or switch name and the port number (together, called the channel), and shelf ID of this enclosure. Examples are 8a.1 and switch:5.1.
The logical identifier of this enclosure. This a form of the World-Wide Name (WWN).
The product ID of the shelf hardware module that provides the enclosure monitoring function. Example is LRC.
The name of the vendor of this enclosure. Example is Xyratex.
The model name of this enclosure. Example is DiskShelf14.
The revision number of this enclosure.
The serial number of this enclosure.
The number of disk bays in this enclosure.
The list of disks present by bay number in this enclosure.
The maximum number of power supplies in this enclosure.
The list of power supplies present in the enclosure. Numbering is from left to right in their intended location in the shelf, while facing the supplies.

The list of serial numbers of power supplies present in the enclosure. Not all shelves are able to report the power supply serial number. Communication errors may make the serial number unavailable. Numbering is from left to right in their intended locati
The list of failed power supplies in this enclosure, numbered as in enclPowerSuppliesPresent.
The maximum number of fans or fan modules monitored by this enclosure. R100/R150 shelf power supply fans are not included in this number.

The list of fans or fan modules present and for which status is known in this enclosure. Fans are numbered left-to-right as facing the fans. R100/R150 shelf power supply fans are not included in this list.
The list of failed fans or fan modules in this enclosure. Fans are numbered as described in enclFansPresent.
The maximum number of temperature sensors monitored by this enclosure.

The list of temperature sensors present and for which status is known in this enclosure. Temperature sensors are numbered top-to-bottom and left-to-right, beginning with the front of the enclosure, then the rear, as the modules containing them are faced.
The list of temperature sensors reporting overtemperature failure in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of temperature sensors reporting overtemperature warning in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of temperature sensors reporting undertemperature failure in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of temperature sensors reporting undertemperature warning in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of temperatures reported by all temperature sensors in the enclosure, including the ambient temperature. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of overtemperature failure thresholds for all temperature sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of overtemperature warning thresholds for all temperature sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of undertemperature failure thresholds for all temperature sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The list of undertemperature warning thresholds for all temperature sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in TempSensorsPresent.
The number of enclosure services electronics modules that it is possible for this enclosure to detect and/or monitor.

The list those enclosure services electronics modules present in this enclosure. Numbering is from left-to-right or top-to-bottom in their intended location in the shelf, while facing the electronics modules. It is normal for the R200 FC-AT module to be r
The list of serial numbers of the enclosure services electronics modules present in this enclosure. The order follows that of enclElectronicsPresent.
The list of failed electronics elements. Valid only if enclElectronicsPresent shows that some are present.
The number of voltage sensors monitored by this enclosure.

The list of voltage sensors present and for which status is known in this enclosure. Voltage sensors are numbered top-to-bottom and left-to-right, beginning with the front of the enclosure, then the rear, as the modules containing them are faced.
The list of voltage sensors reporting overvoltage failure in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of voltage sensors reporting overvoltage warning in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of voltage sensors reporting undervoltage failure in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of voltage sensors reporting undervoltage warning in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of overvoltage failure thresholds for all voltage sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of overvoltage warning thresholds for all voltage sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of undervoltage failure thresholds for all voltage sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of undervoltage warning thresholds for all voltage sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The list of voltages reported by all voltage sensors in the enclosure, Sensors are numbered as in VoltSensorsPresent.
The number of current sensors monitored by this enclosure.

The list of current sensors present and for which status is known in this enclosure. Current sensors are numbered top-to-bottom and left-to-right, beginning with the front of the enclosure, then the rear, as the modules containing them are faced.
The list of current sensors reporting overcurrent failure in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in CurSensorsPresent.
The list of current sensors reporting overcurrent warning in this enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in CurSensorsPresent.
The list of overcurrent failure thresholds for all current sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in CurSensorsPresent.
The list of overcurrent warning thresholds for all current sensors in the enclosure. Sensors are numbered as in CurSensorsPresent.
The list of currents reported by all current sensors in the enclosure, Sensors are numbered as in CurSensorsPresent.

A unique value for each interface. Its value ranges between 1 and the value of ifNumber. The value for each interface must remain constant at least from one re-initialization of the entity's network management system to the next re- initialization.
A textual string containing information about the interface. This string should include the name of the manufacturer, the product name and the version of the hardware interface.
The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters.
The number of subnetwork-unicast packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol.
The number of non-unicast (i.e., subnetwork- broadcast or subnetwork-multicast) packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol.

The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. This
The number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
The number of packets received via the interface which were discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol.
The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters.
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted to a subnetwork-unicast address, including those that were discarded or not sent.

The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted to a non- unicast (i.e., a subnetwork-broadcast or subnetwork-multicast) address, including those that were discarded or not sent.

The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
The number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors.
The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters.
The number of subnetwork-unicast packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol.
The number of non-unicast (i.e., subnetwork- broadcast or subnetwork-multicast) packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol.

The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. This
The number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
The number of packets received via the interface which were discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol.
The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters.
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted to a subnetwork-unicast address, including those that were discarded or not sent.

The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted to a non- unicast (i.e., a subnetwork-broadcast or subnetwork-multicast) address, including those that were discarded or not sent.

The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
The number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors.
A number that identifies this entry for the SIS volume.
The path to the SIS volume.
Indicates whether SIS is enabled on the volume or not.
Current status of the SIS volume.
The progress of the current SIS operation.
Indicates whether it is a regular or snapvaulted SIS volume.
The schedule for the SIS opertions.
The starting time of the last completed SIS opertion.
The ending time of the last completed SIS operation.
The total amount of data in KBytes that the last completed SIS operation had processed.
The error that the last SIS operation encountered if it failed.
The total amount of data in KBytes that the last completed SIS operation had processed.
A number that identifies this entry for the referenced file system.
The name for the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is in use on the referenced file system.
The total disk space in KBytes that is in use on the referenced file system.
The disk space in KBytes of disk space that is saved by compression on the referenced filesystem.
The disk space in KBytes of disk space that is saved by compression on the referenced filesystem.
The percentage of disk space saved by compression on the referenced filesystem.
